710117f-a.text:
Grand Opera House (originally known as Pike's Opera House),
Eighth Avenue at N. W. corner of 23rd Street.
In the 1870's, Jay Gould and Colonel James Fisk had executive offices of the Erie Railroad here.
This theatre has one of the largest stages in New York.
June 1925.

The Opera House will be demolished as per "The New York Herald Tribune,"of July 18, 1937, which also includes a historical resume, pertinent to this structure.

711691f-a.text:
(1)  23rd Street, north side, west from and including Eighth Avenue.  On the N.W. corner is the Grand Opera House, formerly Pike's Opera House, built in 1868.  In the background, the apartment houses of new London Terrace near completion.
June 3, 1930.

(2)  The same, but not showing Eighth Avenue.
June 3, 1930.

711695f-a.text:
23rd Street, north side, east from building adjoining the N.E. corner of Eighth Avenue.  The clearing was left by the demolition of a row of ten four-story houses, 263-245 West 23rd Street.

23rd Street at S.E. corner of Eighth Avenue.

March 6, 1931

710116f-a.text:
259-249 and 241-237 Eighth Ave., west side, south from and including West 23rd., to and including 22nd Streets. The 19-story apartment house is known as No. 300 West 23rd Street [not 310, as noted on original photo], and is at the S.W. corner of Eighth Ave., ask bearing Nos. 249-259 of the latter Street.

December 26, 1936.

P.L. Sperr

710119f-a.text:
Eighth Avenue (right), at the N.W. corner of West 23rd Street (left), showing the Grand Opera House. This house was built and opened by Samuel N. Pike as Pike's Opera Souse, January 9, 1868. James Fisk and Jay Could purchased the house in March 1869 and gave it the present name.
1670s
4
American Studio, photo
87 Nassau Street, N.Y.C.
Gift of Urbrock Collection

710122f-b.text:
Eighth Avenue, north from '. 23rd Street, showing mainly buildings on the west side of same. At the left is the Grand Opera House, built by Samuel N. Pike as Pike's Opera House and opened January 9, 1868 with a performance of "Il Trovatore." James Fisk and Jay Gould purchased it in March 1869. The latter wibhdrew and the theatre became identified with Fisk. At his death, his formerr oartner took over.
View 1: January 22, 1929
View 2: June 3, 1930
P. L. Sperr
